definitions.definition: to take something from a person, shop, etc. without permission and without intending to return it or pay for it
definitions.sensetop: steal from somebody/somethingsteal somethingsteal something from somebody/something
definitions.labels: (figurative)(figurative)(British English)(North American English)(British English)(North American English)(especially British English)(especially British English)(especially North American English)(especially British English)

examples.text: I'll report you to the police if I catch you stealing again.
We found out he'd been stealing from us for years.
He stole a car from the parking lot of a mall.
It's a crime to handle **stolen goods**.
He was charged with possession of **stolen property**.
They accused the president of **stealing the election** *(= winning it by cheating)*.

definitions.definition: to move secretly and quietly so that other people do not notice you

examples.text: She stole out of the room so as not to wake the baby.
A chill stole over her body.

definitions.definition: to run to the next base before another player from your team hits the ball, so that you are closer to scoring

examples.text: He tried to steal second base but was out.

definitions.definition: to look at somebody/something quickly so that nobody sees you doing it
to make somebody fall in love with you
to kiss somebody suddenly or secretly
to gain an advantage over somebody by doing something before them

examples.text: The company is looking at ways to steal a march on its European competitors.

definitions.definition: to attract more attention and praise than other people in a particular situation

examples.text: As always, the children stole the show.
British bands stole the show at this year’s awards.

definitions.definition: to get the attention, success, etc. that somebody else was expecting, usually by saying or doing what they had intended to say or do

wordOrigin: Old English stelan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch stelen and German stehlen.
